meaning_mnemonic: This word has the kanji for <kanji>one</kanji> and <kanji>period</kanji>. You only have one period to live in so this is the only <vocabulary>lifetime</vocabulary> you get. Unless you're reborn, but that will probably be in the next age, not this one. So one lifetime for you!
This word is so simple. <kanji>North</kanji> + <kanji>west</kanji> = <vocabulary>northwest</vocabulary>.

You proceed <kanji>straight</kanji> ahead to <kanji>go</kanji> somewhere because you're <vocabulary>going directly</vocabulary> there. You're making a <vocabulary>nonstop</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>direct</vocabulary> trip — no pitstops or detours.

直行 is commonly seen in transportation contexts, especially when talking about flights. It's also often used in business settings to describe traveling directly to a destination without making any stops, like visiting a client’s office straight from your home.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means start, and this verb means to begin or to start. 始まる is the intransitive version, so it doesn't take a direct object. A war begins, for example, or the new school term starts. No direct object, right? Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wait</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wait</vocabulary>.

When your <kanji>relationship</kanji> with someone is really <kanji>good</kanji>, you naturally become <vocabulary>good friend</vocabulary>s. You're always palling around together and acting <vocabulary>buddy-buddy</vocabulary>, so everyone can tell how close your friendship is.

仲良し describes close friends or people who get along really well. The word has a friendly, cute vibe and is often used for kids, families, or anyone with a warm bond.

Western-style eats just means Western-style food. You can call this Western food for short, but in Japan it actually refers to a Japanese genre of food inspired by European dishes. Think omurice (omelette rice) or Napolitan pasta (spaghetti and ketchup). You know, Western-style food.

Your <kanji>exertion</kanji> is <kanji>strong</kanji>. You'd think this means you're working hard or something, but it means <vocabulary>studies</vocabulary> (like studies you have for a test or something). So for this, just imagine yourself exerting yourself really strongly on your homework. These are your <vocabulary>studies</vocabulary> / what you <vocabulary>study</vocabulary>.
The essence of your <kanji>house</kanji> and <kanji>garden</kanji> is your <vocabulary>family</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>household</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>home</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meaning <vocabulary>yard</vocabulary> to your memory bank as well, if you'd like.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>breath</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> (that lets you release your breath when it's born) is a <vocabulary>son</vocabulary>. Nowadays it's cool to have a girl, but back in the day you wanted a son to carry on your underwater basket weaving legacy. That's why this is a son.

You receive <kanji>profit</kanji> at every <kanji>breath</kanji>. What kind of profit is this? It's <vocabulary>interest</vocabulary>. As time goes by and as you take more breaths you gain more bank interest.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When you <kanji>go</kanji> on a <kanji>trip</kanji> you're taking a <vocabulary>trip</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>travel</vocabulary>. You should try to do this occasionally! Perhaps a nice 旅行 to Japan?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>root</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> is the <vocabulary>root</vocabulary> of something. Possibly even more root than root, but we'll stick with root.

根本 generally refers to the root cause or fundamental <vocabulary>basis</vocabulary> of something, like "the root of the problem" or "the fundamental principle."
The <kanji>root</kanji> of your <kanji>roof</kanji> is still your <vocabulary>roof</vocabulary>. If it helps, imagine roots growing out of your roof. They protect you from the rain.

The <kanji>root</kanji> of your <kanji>energy</kanji>. You have to dig deep into your energy, all the way to the origin and source of it, to have enough <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> to deal with this dumb kid who's eating away at your not-root energy. It's all you have, and you need to use it.

This will be easier if you've seen or heard of daikon before. It's a really <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>root</kanji> in the ground that's pretty delicious. It's known as <vocabulary>daikon</vocabulary> in the grocery stores for the most part, though occasionally you'll see it as <vocabulary>Japanese radish</vocabulary> instead.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>. If you're streaming water, it might be <vocabulary>to flush something</vocabulary>. Alternatively, <vocabulary>to pour something</vocabulary> makes a stream of liquid, and <vocabulary>to set something afloat</vocabulary> is to make something flow in the stream.

Where the <kanji>stream</kanji> is <kanji>go</kanji>ing is where everyone's going. That's what tends to be the <vocabulary>trend</vocabulary> of things. Imagine a trend going on in your society right now. Imagine it going down a stream with everyone following it. This word is also used for less desirable trends, like the <vocabulary>prevalence</vocabulary> of infectious diseases.

This is a weird one. You have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>stream</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>first rate</vocabulary> stream material we have here, though. If you think about it, if you only have one stream (instead of a ton of streams), you can put all your effort and energy into it. When you do that, you're making sure it is a <vocabulary>first rate</vocabulary> stream in terms of quality and anything else.
The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>stream</kanji>, that's where everything comes from. That is the <vocabulary>mainstream</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>extinguish</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to extinguish something</vocabulary>. You can also use this word to say <vocabulary>to erase something</vocabulary>, like data, and <vocabulary>to turn something off</vocabulary>, like the lights or the power. Technically you're extinguishing the data, as well as the lights or power, right?
Throw this onto a number and you have yourself the number of <vocabulary>times</vocabulary> something has increased. For example, ３倍 means something increased "three fold."

Something that is <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>double</vocabulary> (or it is just simply <vocabulary>two times</vocabulary>). Of course, this all works with things like 三倍, 百倍, and 四十二倍 as well.
The <kanji>shop</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who is a "member" (aka employed by) the shop. This is the <vocabulary>shop staff</vocabulary>.
<kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji>s means <vocabulary>all members</vocabulary>. This is also a fancy way to say <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>members</kanji> are the <vocabulary>employees</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>staff</vocabulary>.
A "company" (会社) <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who works at a company. This is a <vocabulary>company employee</vocabulary>. There are many of these in Japan. Most of them are drunk.

The <kanji>wide</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji>... this isn't helpful on its own, but this wide island is <vocabulary>Hiroshima</vocabulary> (heard of it?). When you do the reading it will make more sense.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>writing</kanji> <kanji>chapter</kanji> is just another name for a piece of <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>, a.k.a. a <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary>. Even if it's only a single <vocabulary>sentence</vocabulary>! 文章 covers just about every type of writing there is.

Although 文章 is pretty versatile, it most often refers to a complete piece of longer writing, like an essay, novel, short story, or poem. But even something super short like a tanka or haiku can be called 文章, as long as it's a complete work by itself.
The <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>chapter</kanji> has a much simpler way of describing it, which is <vocabulary>chapter two</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> refers to <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary> thing. This is the <vocabulary>number one</vocabulary> place you can get. In fact, it's simply the <vocabulary>best</vocabulary>.
You have the <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> and 一位 (first place). By adding the prefix 第, you can make it a little more formal, but it still means <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>.

Remember how 東京 is Tokyo? Add <kanji>metropolis</kanji> to it and you get the <vocabulary>Tokyo Metropolis</vocabulary>.

東京都 is basically one of Japan's prefectures, but they call it a "metropolis" instead. It's the capital and the largest city in all of Japan!

The <kanji>capital</kanji> <kanji>metropolis</kanji> back in the day was <vocabulary>Kyoto</vocabulary>. Now of course the capital is Tokyo, but kanji doesn't know this. That's why Kyoto is the capital metropolis!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>move</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>moving</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>... think about the "things" that move. Technically it could be a lot of things (aka basically anything), but in this case we are talking about moving living things. We won't include humans, because humans are too good to be called things. This refers to <vocabulary>animals</vocabulary> instead.

When you <kanji>carry</kanji> your <kanji>move</kanji>ments (or carry something along with your movements, like weights, for example) you are doing <vocabulary>exercise</vocabulary>. Speaking of which, perhaps you've been studying kanji a little too much lately. Time to get up and do some squats or play some <vocabulary>sport</vocabulary>s.

This word can also mean more abstract kinds of <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>, like social or political movements that strive for change. It can also be used when describing <vocabulary>motion</vocabulary> in physics.
<kanji>Sell</kanji>ing <kanji>merchandise</kanji> is <vocabulary>business</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>commerce</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>trade</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>merchandise</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>merchant</vocabulary>. You want to buy something or you just looking?
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>bad</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>bad</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bad person</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is an <vocabulary>evil woman</vocabulary>. Surprisingly, "mother in law" is not one of the meanings for this word.
The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>bad</kanji> is <vocabulary>the worst</vocabulary>. At least it can’t get any worse…

Your <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> is your <vocabulary>family</vocabulary>. They live in the same house as you and they're part of your "tribe." This is closer than family, though (depending on how you look at family). This is your <vocabulary>immediate family</vocabulary> because these are the people you live with and give birth to, etc.
A <kanji>peoples</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> (or tribe of peoples) is a group that all stick together. They are one single <vocabulary>ethnic group</vocabulary>. What's your 民族?
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>deep</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>deep</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>deep</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle of the night</vocabulary>. It doesn't get any deeper than that before you start coming out of the night to start the next day.
The <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>deep</kanji>ness is the <vocabulary>water depth</vocabulary>. You should check this before diving into the water so you don't hit your face.

The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>deep</kanji> is the <vocabulary>deepest</vocabulary>.

最深 is a formal word used in geology to describe the deepest point of things like caves and oceans.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

球 has a slightly technical sound and highlights the sphere shape of the object you're talking about. It's most commonly used to refer to <vocabulary>sports ball</vocabulary>s (as a more formal alternative to ボール).

<kanji>Field</kanji> <kanji>Sphere</kanji>! The greatest sport to grace this earth since a very similar (aka the same) sport, <vocabulary>baseball</vocabulary>. Think about it, you play on a field and you use a little sphere. Awesome!

Don't think of this as a <kanji>juvenile</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji>. Think of 話 the vocab word, which means "story." If you do that, you get a "juvenile story." What's a juvenile story? It's a <vocabulary>children's story</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>floor</kanji> is the <vocabulary>first floor</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>floor one</vocabulary>). In Japan, that means the <vocabulary>ground floor</vocabulary>. Pretty simple.
The <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>floor</kanji> is the <vocabulary>second floor</vocabulary>. In Japan, that means the floor above the ground floor. Going up!
You know that 四十二 means "forty two." So, as long as you know <kanji>floor</kanji> you'll know this means <vocabulary>forty-second floor</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>cold</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>.

寒い is used specifically for when you feel cold. You can say it when you're outside on a chilly winter day, for example, or when you walk into a cold room. It can even be used as a response to unfunny jokes that leave you cold.

This is the adjective form of <kanji>hot</kanji>... but we're going to call it <vocabulary>hot weather</vocabulary>. Why? Because there's a difference between something that's hot and the weather or atmosphere being hot. This is that kind of hot, as in..."Damn, man, it's hot out here!"

For a <kanji>period of time</kanji> you have to <kanji>wait</kanji>. During this waiting period, you’re building up an <vocabulary>expectation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>anticipation</vocabulary> for something to happen a certain way. Waiting, expecting, waiting, expecting…

期待 specifically refers to the feeling of expectation or anticipation for a desired outcome.

The <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> isn't the pitiful amount of time you spend studying. It's something much bigger: the <vocabulary>school term</vocabulary>. Ugh, how much longer is this study period of time???

The <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is a period of time of time. If anything, just notice how many times the word "time" is used and you'll remember this word means <vocabulary>time</vocabulary>. The meaning is a specific type of time, though. This is talking about a <vocabulary>season</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be 時間 or something.
<kanji>Plant</kanji> <kanji>things</kanji> are <vocabulary>plants</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>vegetation</vocabulary>.
You know that a 医者 is a doctor. So what is a <kanji>tooth</kanji> doctor? A <vocabulary>dentist</vocabulary>. Seriously, don't forget to floss. 歯医者 hate when you forget to floss.

A <kanji>tooth</kanji> <kanji>bug</kanji>... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a <vocabulary>cavity</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>warm</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>spring</kanji> (like the water kind of spring) is a <vocabulary>hot spring</vocabulary>. These are really nice. You should go to them in Japan.

The <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s is how many degrees warm it is in here. Of course, there can be very few warm degrees as well, making it very cold. What is all this? It's the <vocabulary>temperature</vocabulary>.
Put aside your steampunk blimp fantasies for a moment. A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>harbor</kanji> is an <vocabulary>airport</vocabulary>, nothing more.
The <kanji>hot water</kanji> of <kanji>tea</kanji>. That is part of the ceremony that goes into the <vocabulary>tea ceremony</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Hot water</kanji>'s <kanji>energy</kanji> isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the <vocabulary>steam</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vapor</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>climb</kanji> so the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to climb</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to ascend</vocabulary>), if that's the kind of thing you're into.
<kanji>Climb</kanji> a <kanji>mountain</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>mountain climbing</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wear</kanji> so this word means <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>short</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>short</vocabulary>.

This word is used to describe things that are short in length, not in height, like 短いトンネル (a short tunnel) or 短いスカート (a short skirt). It can also be used for things that are <vocabulary>brief</vocabulary>, like speeches, meetings, or messages.
The <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>sword</kanji> is the <vocabulary>short sword</vocabulary>. What's another word for a short sword? It's a <vocabulary>dagger</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is the <vocabulary>short term</vocabulary>. You know not to think short term anyways, right? You're learning kanji, after all.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>suit</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to suit</vocabulary>. 

This word also means <vocabulary>to come together</vocabulary> as well. Presumably when something suits something else, it comes together with it flawlessly. That's why this word also has this other meaning (and it will be important for future vocab as well).

You've hopefully seen the word 決める before. This is similar, except instead of deciding something, something gets decided. Rules are decided, a schedule gets decided — that kind of thing. It's intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. So 決まる means to be decided. Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!

We have <kanji>alcohol</kanji> and the noun form of 飲む (to drink). So you know this has to do with drinking alcohol. It means a <vocabulary>boozer</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>drunkard</vocabulary>, someone who drinks a lot of alcohol!

酒飲み literally means "alcohol drinker," and it usually implies that the person consumes a lot of alcohol. This is a casual word and it can sound playful (like teasing a friend) or mildly critical depending on the situation and tone.

The <kanji>chirp</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a sound an animal makes. Sure, it works for birds (which chirp), but it also works with most other animals as well. So, we call this an <vocabulary>animal cry</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>thing</kanji> you <kanji>drink</kanji> is a <vocabulary>beverage</vocabulary>.

You've seen 聞く by now hopefully. This is similar, but instead of meaning "to hear" it means <vocabulary>to be hearable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be audible</vocabulary>. To remember this, just think about how you can hear a こえ (voice) coming from the middle of the word 聞こえる. It's audible to you too, right?

聞こえる is used when sounds reach your ears on their own, like "I can hear music from next door." It's more about what comes to your ears, not what you're trying to listen to. That's why it also means <vocabulary>to be able to hear</vocabulary>.

Remember how 心配 means "a worry" and 事 can mean "thing"? Well, if you have a worry over some specific thing, then you probably have some <vocabulary>cares</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>worries</vocabulary>. What are your 心配事 these days?

The <kanji>sound</kanji> <kanji>read</kanji>ing. What could this be...? Wait a sec, think to Japanese and kanji. What's the reading that uses sounds from another place, specifically China? That's the <vocabulary>Chinese reading</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>on'yomi</vocabulary>. Sounds familiar?

You know that <vocabulary>運転</vocabulary> has to do with driving, right? And you know that <kanji>手</kanji> often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A <vocabulary>driver</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>leaf</kanji> that <kanji>fall</kanji>s are <vocabulary>fallen leaves</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>father</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is your <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>mother</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is the <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary>.

Remember 一番目? This is just like that, but with three, making it <vocabulary>the third thing</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>the third</vocabulary>.

Again, think about your eyeball collection. This time, you're showing someone the third eyeball in your display case. It just happens to be third in line, but honestly it's just as beautiful as the two that come before it.

Your <kanji>speak</kanji>ing <kanji>way</kanji> is… your <vocabulary>way of speaking</vocabulary>, or your <vocabulary>speaking style</vocabulary>. This includes your tone of voice, speed, and even how you use gestures when talking. It's more about the whole way you communicate, not just the wording or how you phrase things.

Do you remember the word 転がる? This is kind of similar, instead of rolling, this is more for when something falls and hits the ground. It means <vocabulary>to fall over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone falling off a chair face first into the dirt and making a ぶ sound.

I bet you remember 集める means "to collect something." But this time you're not collecting something. Instead, something just… collects. In other words, 集まる means to come together or to gather. Friends come together, or fans gather at a venue — that sort of thing. No direct object needed, since this is intransitive. Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!

You've seen how 落ちる means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. You can remember this because you kind of <reading>toss</reading> (とす) something and it drops to the ground, making this word mean <vocabulary>to drop something</vocabulary>.
By now you should know that 終わる means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be <vocabulary>the end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the finish</vocabulary>.

We've seen a few times where 電 refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the <kanji>end</kanji> train for this word would refer to the <vocabulary>last train</vocabulary>.
You should know 開ける by now. This word is similar to that, except it has to do with when things are just open. It's the same thing, though. The meaning is also <vocabulary>to open</vocabulary>.

You know that 起きる means "to wake up", but did you learn its secondary meaning, "to occur"? Well, this word means only <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Just imagine an incident occurring involving a uranium <reading>core</reading> (こる) to remember that this means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. After all, uranium core incidents don't wake up, do they?
You know that 心配 is "a worry." What about the verb version of that? It would be <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary>.

You learned 鳴く means "to chirp" (or some other animal sound). 鳴る is similar, but it's used when something just makes a sound, like a phone ringing, a bell jingling, or thunder rumbling. So 鳴る means <vocabulary>to sound</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to ring</vocabulary>. You know this because 鳴る can also be used for when your stomach rumbles: "<reading>rrrr</reading>" (る)!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. One of the kanji's meanings is <kanji>sing</kanji> so the verb vocab version of this is <vocabulary>to sing</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>hand</kanji> (or person, as you know 手 often refers to a person) that <kanji>win</kanji>s gets to do <vocabulary>as one pleases</vocabulary> without regard for anyone else.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means transmit, and this verb version is to be transmitted or to be conveyed. It's intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. A message is transmitted, or your feelings are conveyed — that kind of thing. Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!

This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you <kanji>join</kanji> together with someone at a <kanji>metropolis</kanji>, you do it <vocabulary>at your convenience</vocabulary>. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about.

This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
You know that 映る is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is <vocabulary>to project</vocabulary>.
You hopefully remember that 要求 means "demand" . When you make that a verb, it becomes <vocabulary>to demand something</vocabulary>.

What is something that will first <kanji>extinguish</kanji> something and then <kanji>change</kanji> it? One thing I can think of is your body. It takes in food, extinguishes it in your stomach, then changes it into things your body can use (and then excrete). That's why this "extinguish-change" process is your <vocabulary>digestion</vocabulary>.

This takes the <kanji>luck</kanji> meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of <vocabulary>luck</vocabulary> because of it.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes off. Something is removed. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to come off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be removed</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>energy</kanji> of the <kanji>warm</kanji>th will cause the <vocabulary>temperature</vocabulary> to go up and down. Energy goes up? Higher temperature because of more movement and activity. Energy goes down? Well, temperature gets colder and slower.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is <kanji>he</kanji> but plural. The "ra" makes it plural, making it "<vocabulary>they</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>them</vocabulary>." In modern Japanese, this word generally refers to a group of men or boys, but it can also be used for mixed groups as well.
誰 is <kanji>who</kanji>, 誰か is like asking "who?" If you don't know who it is, you just know it's <vocabulary>someone</vocabulary>.

You're <kanji>tired</kanji> from <kanji>labor</kanji>. From this, you're showing <vocabulary>fatigue</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>weariness</vocabulary>.

疲労 is a little formal, so you might encounter it more often in writing than in conversation.

You know that the kanji refers to a <kanji>floor</kanji> (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a 〜. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.

Note that floor-counting systems can vary across different countries. In Japan the ground floor is generally called 一階, with the floors above being 二階, 三階, and so on.
A <kanji>metropolis</kanji> <kanji>city</kanji> is a <vocabulary>city</vocabulary>. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word.

A <kanji>leaf</kanji> of the things you <kanji>say</kanji> is like a leaf from a tree of speaking. That leaf is a part of the whole language, it is a single <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>, though it can add up to be a <vocabulary>language</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>manner of speech</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
The <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji>! It's where we live and the planet we call home. It's <vocabulary>the earth</vocabulary>!
If you <kanji>meet</kanji> enough <kanji>member</kanji>s you will become a <vocabulary>member</vocabulary> yourself!
A <kanji>member</kanji> of a <kanji>boat</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>sailor</vocabulary>.

When <kanji>metropolis</kanji>es <kanji>meet</kanji> they become an <vocabulary>urban area</vocabulary>. This word is often used to mean <vocabulary>city</vocabulary> as opposed to the country or rural areas.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
When you're talking or writing a paper, the part that <kanji>falls</kanji> at the end is the <vocabulary>conclusion</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>period of time</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>interval</vocabulary> of time.

When you <kanji>go</kanji> to <kanji>move</kanji> you're actually making an <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>. This word can also mean <vocabulary>behavior</vocabulary>, since your actions are what make up your behavior.
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>gather</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>gathering</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>plant</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to plant something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to grow something</vocabulary>.

Who plays a <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji> to you? Your <vocabulary>boss</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>leader</vocabulary>!

親分 is an informal and sort of old-fashioned word for someone who's in charge of close-knit groups, like in gangs or traditional trades such as carpentry and fishing. The 親分 is like a parent figure who takes care of the other members.
Remember how you learned that 文字 can mean "characters?" Well make a <kanji>face</kanji> out of those characters and you've made a <vocabulary>kaomoji</vocabulary>! ʅ(◔౪◔ ) ʃ
A <kanji>club</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>clubroom</vocabulary>!
Remember how you learned that 大学院 means "graduate school" and 大学生 means "college student?" Well smush them together and you have a  <vocabulary>graduate student</vocabulary>!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>move</kanji>s you make are your <vocabulary>activity</vocabulary>.

活動 includes all kinds of activities, including nature activities, club activities, economic activity, and so on!

A <kanji>festival</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> literally means "festival day," as in a day for Shinto festivals or rituals. These days, though, it really just means <vocabulary>holiday</vocabulary>.

Usually this will be a <vocabulary>national holiday</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>public holiday</vocabulary>, since some Japanese public holidays are based on Shinto festival days. 祭日 was actually the official term for public holidays prior to World War II. It sounds a little old-fashioned today, but you may still encounter it occasionally.

Something you <kanji>wear</kanji>, and <kanji>wear</kanji> again, is something you <vocabulary>steadily</vocabulary> wear. You do it so often, it's reliable. Also, if you wear something this much it's steadily wearing away too.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>suffer</kanji>, and the verb is all about when you make someone else suffer. That's why it's <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to harass</vocabulary>.

You need to differentiate this from 苦しむ, which is about when YOU suffer. You can remember that 苦しめる is about making someone else suffer with this mnemonic: Who made you suffer? <reading>She ma</reading>de (しめ) me suffer! She's so mean!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>finish</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to finish something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to end something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning you finish something, like a long day at work!

You need to differentiate this from 終わる, which is when something just ends on its own. 終える is about when you make something end. Remember it like this: Canadians always end their sentences with "eh" え, right? Well that's how you know they're ending their sentence. Just listen for the "eh," eh?

You <kanji>solve</kanji> a problem by working toward the <kanji>answer</kanji>. This is the act of <vocabulary>solving</vocabulary>, which eventually leads to the final <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>solution</vocabulary>!

解答 specifically refers to solving problems and giving answers with a correct solution, often for structured contexts like exams or math problems. It can also refer to the answer or solution itself.

When you're doing a <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>swim</kanji>, you're really just… well, <vocabulary>swimming</vocabulary>.

Note that 水泳 will usually refer to swimming as a sport or organized activity. When talking about swimming as a general action, 泳ぎ and 泳ぐ are more commonly used.

A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>west</kanji> <kanji>ocean</kanji>, you say? It's gotta be the <vocabulary>Atlantic Ocean</vocabulary>.

If you think about it from Japan's perspective, the Atlantic is a big, faraway ocean to the west, right?
